Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mobile and Ubiquitous Computing Technologies for Young Children with Chronic Health Conditions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
An emergent area of impact and significance is the application of mobile and ubiquitous computing technologies to chronic healthcare. The long-lasting nature of chronic medical conditions makes record-keeping and long-term analysis of diagnostic and evaluative measures extremely important and challenging. Capture and access technologies, i.e., ubiquitous computing technologies that enable recording and access to recorded data, are particularly promising for monitoring the effectiveness of interventions for chronic conditions. Health and behavioral data can be captured, analyzed, and mined over time, providing valuable evidence for tracking the progress of interventions. This research will examine the role that novel mobile and ubiquitous computing technologies can play in record-keeping for chronic care of young children.

Specifically, this research addresses three major challenges. First, technological interventions must be developed that support better record keeping and associated visualization and hypothesis testing to allow caregivers to understand the impacts of their pharmaceutical and behavioral interventions. Second, these interventions must be understood in the short-term to support testing of clinical efficacy and also over the lifetime of these patients whose chronic conditions can span several decades. Third, the focus of these technologies must be not only on capturing and allowing access to appropriate data but also in accomplishing these goals while easing the extensive burden on families.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project focused on mobile and ubiquitous computing solutions to support children with disabilities, such as autism, and chronic health conditions, resulting in a deep understanding of the concerns of families coping with chronic disorders for children [Cramer et al 2011; Escobedo et al 2012; Hayes et al 2010; Hirano et al 2010; Tentori & Hayes 2010]. This project has enabled us to develop community based participatory research methods [Hayes 2011; Mankoff et al 2010; Cheng et al 2014; Hayes et al 2014]. Interested individuals can download some of the software products by searching the Google Play store or Apple App Store for VidCoach and HygieneHelper (free). Additional research data and software are available by contacting the PI.

Broader Impacts: Twenty-two undergraduates participated in the project, including 10 women and 3 students with disabilities, resulting in eight being co-authors on peer-reviewed publications. This work was incorporated into two undergraduate courses at UCI and presented at eight community-oriented forums, serving over 1000 teachers, parents, and other stakeholders in the autism community. The hundreds of children and adults with neurodevelopmental disabilities and chronic illnesses who participated in this work may have been helped through use of our research prototypes, which we hope to make more broadly available in the coming years.

 


Last Modified: 04/28/2015
Modified by: Gillian Hayes
